definition.value: Analysis of....A substance or mixture of substances, the composition of which is known within specified limits, and one or more of the properties of which is sufficiently well established to be used for the calibration of an apparatus, the assessment of a measuring method or for assigning values to materials. Reference materials are available from national laboratories in many countries [e.g. National Institute for Standards and Technology (NIST), USA.; Community Bureau of Reference, UK].

An analytical instrument specifically designed to be deployed (permanently or semi-permanently) at the location of the sample (as opposed to sample taken to the instrument) that operates automatically or semi-automatically
Method analysis that is implemented by deployment of device that has been designed and built to carry out the analysis autonomously, i.e. without direct human intervention

A group of data points that are nominally the same numeric value becuase they are equally valid estimates of a property of the same population, but due to random error will be scattered based on the distrubution model applicable in the context of process of measuring the data.

A sampling plan that can be expected to capture a sample that adequately reflects the properties of interest of the parent population. A representative sample may be a random sample or, for example, a stratified sample, depending upon the objective of sampling and the characteristics of the population. The degree of representativeness of the sample may be limited by cost or convenience.
Ruggedness means that the precision and accuracy of the method are insensitive to minor changes in environmental and procedural variables, laboratories, personnel, etc.
One of a predefined set of abbreviations for magnitude values of scientific numbers published by under the Systeme International of Units specification
Equivalent unit expression using the SI units for a non-SI unit

A portion of material selected from a larger quantity of material. The term needs to be qualified, e.g. bulk sample, representative sample, primary sample, bulked sample, test sample. The term 'sample' implies the existence of a sampling error, i.e. the results obtained on the portions taken are only estimates of the concentration of a constituent or the quantity of a property present in the parent material. If there is no or negligible sampling error, the portion removed is a test portion, aliquot or specimen. The term 'specimen' is used to denote a portion taken under conditions such that the sampling variability cannot be assessed (usually because the population is changing), and is assumed, for convenience, to be zero. The manner of selection of the sample should be prescribed in a sampling plan.

label.value: When an instrument, or instrument component, is used to perform a sampling process prior to analysis

definition.value: Method of analysis using a chemical sensor device to determine the concentration or amount of chemical substance
When an analytical instrument or wet chemical method has been used to do separation of a mixture prior to detection
Processing of particulate material into separate fractions of different particle size
A homogeneous mixture of two or more chemical entities in the solid, liquid or gas phase
Process of applying ultrasonic fequencies of sound to a solution in order to aid the process of dissolution
Ability of a method to detect one element in the presence of another element.

A specifically selected portion of a material taken from a dynamic system and assumed to be representative of the parent material at the time it is taken. Although the specimen may not be reproducible in time, e.g. it may be taken from a flowing stream or a portion of blood, no separable sampling error exists since this error is unavoidably included with the corresponding error of the estimate of the property, function or analyte being studied. A specimen may be considered as a special type of sample, taken primarily in time rather than in space. The term 'specimen' has been used both as a representative unit and as a nonrepresentative (often better than most) unit of a population, usually in clinical, biological and mineralogical collections. 'Collections' in this case is used as either a noun or verb. This usage is almost always self-evident, and thus would not be confused with a time-type sample.
Where an additional amount of the analyte has been added to a sample in order to evaluate the accuracy of a procedure

A published standard method of chemical analysis that delineates sample processing, calibration, instrument setup, sample measurment, result calculation an method validation.  Published by an organizational entity of high repute.

Documented set of actions to perform in a chronological sequence to perform an analysis or operate an instrument.  This differs from a standard method of analysis in that it is not ruggedly tested by multiple independent entities.  Normally developed for in-house use and with a specific scope.
Where a chemical entity is used the role of a standard to calibrate a chemical analysis process
Values calculated by applying statistical equations to a set of replicate data that is derived from the same population
Use of a control chart to monitor a chemical or manufacturer process based on statistics of the historical data of the same process
Process of mechanical movement of a solution either by hand for automated device in order to aid dissolution of one or more solutes

A known highly concentrated liquid solution prepared by dissolving a solid chemical substance in a solvent such that the concentration of the chemical substance can be accurately calculated.  The concentration of the chemical substance is too high for direct use and thus must be diluted a procedure.
Analysis of the composition and/or bonding in a substance in order to determine its molecular/ionic structure

Process of taking small representative samples of a larger amount of material in order to subsequently process and analyze in exactly the same way.  Normally performed to allow calculation of a mean value of the analyte property and estimate the precision of the chemical analysis process.
An array of data recorded as a function of time (i.e. all other variables held constant)
Reference units from the Units of Measure Ontology (UO) unless not defined in that ontology
In what situation(s) is a chemical analysis procedure targeted for use in, eg. clinical trial, quality assurance, etc.

Chemical analysis process where a solution based sample is chemically converted to gas of known chemical composition, so that the difference in mass can be used to calculate the concentration of the analyte.

Processes in chemical analysis that are performed using traditional bench glassware physically manipulated by an analyst.  These processes are historically how chemical analysis was done before the development of modern instrumentation.
Methods of chemical analysis that are performed using traditional bench glassware physically manipulated by an analyst
Solution prepared from an intermediate stock solution intended to be used directly in a chemical analysis procedure
Fraction of a chemical substance in the vapor phase under the existing  environmental conditions
The legal name of a manufacturing entity
One or more chemical entities interacting through chemical reaction(s) with properties different than the chemical entities alone
One or more chemical entities interacting through chemical reaction(s) with properties different than the chemical entities alone where the system plays an important biological role
Text based data file that can be in a number of delimited, e.g. CSV, JSON, standardized e.g. JCAMP, MOL, XML or freeform formats
File format developed by the Joint Committee on Atomic and Molecular Physical Data (JCAMP) for exchange of instrument data
Standardized markup language for structured organization of annotated information where the annotation is accomplished through the use of element tags
Javascript object notation (JSON) is a format used to represent name/value pairs of information
A W3C recommended format that encodes RDF triples in the JSON specification
Example datum, data or data arrays that are used to show the quality/capbilities of a chemical analysis methodology

An analysis of a material carried out using two independent analytical methodologies with the highest confidence in its accuracy in that all known or suspected sources of bias have been fully investigated or accounted for

The concentration reported for the analysis of a reference material where there is the highest confidence in its accuracy in that all known or suspected sources of bias have been fully investigated or accounted for
